entry.title: Navier-Stokes Equations in the Wavenumber Space

link.title: Navier-Stokes Equations in the Wavenumber Space

entry.content:
Consider a 3D turbulent fluid flow occupying a periodic cubic box of side length $L$. Any field variable $f( m{x})$, where $ m{x}=(x_l),$ $x_l\in[0,L]$ for $l=1,2,3$, can be expanded in a Fourier series \(f( m{x})=\sum_{ m{k}}\hat{f}( m{k})e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}},\quad m{k}\in rac{2\pi}{L}\mathbb{Z}^3. ag{1}\) It follows that \( abla f=\sum_{ m{k}}(i m{k})\hat{f}( m{k})e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}},\quad abla^2 f=\sum_{ m{k}}(-k^2)\hat{f}( m{k})e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}},\) where $k\equiv| m{k}|=\sqrt{k_lk_l}$. ag{2}

The incompressible Navier–Stokes equations (INSE) governing the turbulent velocity field $ m{u}( m{x},t)$ are \(\partial_t m{u}+ m{u}\cdot abla m{u}=- abla p+ u abla^2 m{u}+ m{f}, \quad abla\cdot m{u}=0. ag{3}\) It can also be written in index form as \( rac{\partial u_l}{\partial t}+u_m rac{\partial u_l}{\partial x_m}=- rac{\partial p}{\partial x_l}+ u rac{\partial^2 u_l}{\partial x_m x_m}+f_l, ag{4}\) \( rac{\partial u_m}{\partial x_m}=0. ag{5}\)

Expanding $ m{u}( m{x},t)$ and $p( m{x},t)$ into Fourier series, the equations in wavenumber space become \(\sum_{ m{k}} rac{\partial \hat{u}_l( m{k},t)}{\partial t}e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}} + igg(\sum_{ m{p}}\hat{u}_m( m{p},t)e^{i m{p}\cdot m{x}} igg) igg(\sum_{ m{q}}(i q_m)\hat{u}_l( m{q},t)e^{i m{q}\cdot m{x}} igg) =\ -\sum_{ m{k}}(ik_l)\hat{p}( m{k},t)e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}} + u\sum_{ m{k}}(-k^2)\hat{u}_l( m{k},t)e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}} +\sum_{ m{k}}\hat{f}_l( m{k},t)e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}}, ag{6}\) and \(\sum_{ m{k}}(ik_m)\hat{u}_m( m{k},t)e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}}=0. ag{7}\) The nonlinear term can be rewritten as \(\sum_{ m{p}}\sum_{ m{q}}(iq_m)\hat{u}_m( m{p},t)\hat{u}_l( m{q},t)e^{i( m{p}+ m{q})\cdot m{x}}.\) We now focus on the coefficient of $e^{i m{k}\cdot m{x}}$ on both sides of the equation, which corresponds to the evolution equation for a single Fourier mode $ m{k}$. To obtain the evolution for a single Fourier mode $ m{k}$, apply the operator \(\mathcal{F}\{\,\cdot\,\}_{ m{k}}\equiv\langle(\,\cdot\,)e^{-i m{k}\cdot m{x}} angle_L\equiv rac{1}{L^3}\int_0^L\int_0^L\int_0^L(\,\cdot\,)e^{-i m{k}\cdot m{x}}\,\mathrm{d} m{x}.\) Using orthogonality of the modes, one finds \( igg( rac{\partial }{\partial t}+ u k^2 igg)\hat{u}_l( m{k},t) = -ik_m\sum_{ m{k}'}\hat{u}_m( m{k}- m{k}',t)\hat{u}_l( m{k}',t) -ik_l\hat{p}( m{k},t) +\hat{f}_l( m{k},t), ag{8}\) and \(ik_m\hat{u}_m( m{k},t)=0. ag{9}\) Here, the derivation of the quadratic nonlinear term has utilized the continuity equation and a variable substitution, $ m{p}+ m{k}’= m{k}$.

An intuition is, in wavenumber space, the velocity $\hat{ m{u}}$ should be normal to the wavevector $ m{k}$ due to the incompressible condition. Hence, it’s natural to ask what will happen if we decompose INSE into two components – one parallel to and one normal to $ m{k}$.

Projecting (8) along $ m{k}$ gives the pressure Poisson equation in wavenumber space \(0 = -i igg( rac{k_lk_n}{k^2} igg)k_m\sum_{ m{k}'}\hat{u}_m( m{k}- m{k}',t)\hat{u}_n( m{k}',t) -ik_l\hat{p}( m{k},t) + igg( rac{k_lk_n}{k^2} igg)\hat{f}_n( m{k},t), ag{10}\) Imposing $({k_lk_n}/{k^2})\hat{f}_n( m{k},t)=0$ ensures divergence-free forcing for numerical simulations of forced incompressible homogeneous isotropic turbulence.

(8) minus (10), we have \( igg( rac{\partial }{\partial t}+ u k^2 igg)\hat{u}_l( m{k},t) = -P_{ln}( m{k})(ik_m)\sum_{ m{k}'}\hat{u}_m( m{k}- m{k}',t)\hat{u}_n( m{k}',t) +P_{ln}( m{k})\hat{f}_n( m{k},t), ag{11}\) here $P_{ln}( m{k})\equiv\delta_{ln}-{(k_lk_n)}/{k^2}$ is the projection tensor, and the pressure is canceled in this equation.

Energy balance equation

We then drop the forcing term in (11), focusing on the intrinsic properties of the turbulent flows governed by INSE. Particularly, we are concerned about how the kinetic energy is transfered in this system. \( igg( rac{\partial }{\partial t}+2 u k^2 igg) rac{1}{2}\hat{u}_l^*( m{k},t)\hat{u}_l( m{k},t) = -P_{ln}( m{k})(ik_m)\sum_{ m{k}'}\hat{u}_m( m{k}- m{k}',t)\hat{u}_n( m{k}',t)\hat{u}_l^*( m{k},t)\) Here the superscript * denotes the complex conjugate.

Take the ensemble average of the above equation, we obtain the balance equation of kinetic energy, $\hat{E}( m{k},t)\equiv\langle rac{1}{2}\hat{u}_l^*( m{k},t)\hat{u}_l( m{k},t) angle$ \( igg( rac{\partial }{\partial t}+2 u k^2 igg)\hat{E}( m{k},t) = k_mP_{ln}( m{k})\,\Im igg\{\sum_{ m{k}'} ig\langle{\hat{u}_l( m{k},t)\hat{u}_m^*( m{k}- m{k}',t)\hat{u}_n^*( m{k}',t)} ig angle igg\}. ag{12}\) $\hat{E}( m{k},t)$ is real-valued, so is the right-hand side. Thus we take its imaginary part, denoted by $\Im$.

We denote the right-hand side as $\hat{T}( m{k},t)$, and – using the Hermitian symmetry of the real-valued velocity field, and a variable substitution – it can also be expressed as \(\hat{T}( m{k},t)=k_mP_{ln}( m{k})\,\Im igg\{\sum_{\substack{ m{p},\, m{q} \ m{k}+ m{p}+ m{q}=0}} ig\langle{\hat{u}_l( m{k},t)\hat{u}_m( m{p},t)\hat{u}_n( m{q},t)} ig angle igg\} \ =\Im igg\{\sum_{\substack{ m{p},\, m{q} \ m{k}+ m{p}+ m{q}=0}} ig\langle{k_m\hat{u}_n( m{k},t)\hat{u}_m( m{p},t)\hat{u}_n( m{q},t)} ig angle igg\}\)

When it is summed over all $ m{k}$, we have \(\sum_{ m{k}}\hat{T}( m{k},t)=\Im igg\{\sum_{\substack{ m{k},\, m{p},\, m{q} \ m{k}+ m{p}+ m{q}=0}} ig\langle{k_m\hat{u}_n( m{k},t)\hat{u}_m( m{p},t)\hat{u}_n( m{q},t)} ig angle igg\} \ =\Im igg\{\sum_{\substack{ m{k},\, m{p},\, m{q} \ m{k}+ m{p}+ m{q}=0}} ig\langle{-(p_m+q_m)\hat{u}_n( m{k},t)\hat{u}_m( m{p},t)\hat{u}_n( m{q},t)} ig angle igg\} \ =\Im igg\{\sum_{\substack{ m{k},\, m{p},\, m{q} \ m{k}+ m{p}+ m{q}=0}} ig\langle{-q_m\hat{u}_n( m{q},t)\hat{u}_m( m{p},t)\hat{u}_n( m{k},t)} ig angle igg\}=-\sum_{ m{q}}\hat{T}( m{q},t)\)

It is straightforward that the summation should be zero, \(\sum_{ m{k}}\hat{T}( m{k},t)=0, ag{13}\) namely, this term merely represents a transfer of energy between modes.

Reference

Batchelor, G. K. (1953). The theory of homogeneous turbulence, Cambridge university press.

McComb, W. D. (1992). The physics of fluid turbulence, Clarendon Press.

Frisch, U. and A. N. Kolmogorov (1995). Turbulence: The Legacy of A. N. Kolmogorov, Cambridge University Press.

Pope, S. B. (2000). Turbulent flows, Cambridge university press.

Any field variable $f(\bm{x})$, where $\bm{x}=(x_l),$ $x_l\in[0,L]$ for $l=1,2,3$, can be expanded in a Fourier series \(f(\bm{x})=\sum_{\bm{k}}\hat{f}(\bm{k})e^{i\bm{k}\cdot\bm{x}},\quad \bm{k}\in\frac{2\pi}{L}\mathbb{Z}^3. \tag{1}\) It follows that \(\nabla f=\sum_{\bm{k}}(i \bm{k})\hat{f}(\bm{k})e^{i\bm{k}\cdot\bm{x}},\quad \nabla^2 f=\sum_{\bm{k}}(-k^2)\hat{f}(\bm{k})e^{i\bm{k}\cdot\bm{x}},\) where $k\equiv|\bm{k}|=\sqrt{k_lk_l}$. \tag{2}

entry.title: About Turbulence
entry.content:
Turbulence (turbulent flows), usually referred to as the most important unsolved problem in classical physics (by Richard Feynman), is ubiquitous in natural and engineering processes - from the water flow in a small faucet to the atmospheric turbulence enveloping the planets. As a fascinating subject in various senses, “turbulence” is associated with a lot of great personalities in fluid physics and mathematics - O. Reynolds, L. Prandtl, von Karman, G.I. Taylor, A.N. Kolmogorov - and appears in many great pieces of art such as Leonardo da Vinci’s manuscripts, The Great Wave off Kanagawa and The Starry Night of Van Gogh.

Yet, formidable challenges go with the beauty of turbulent flows: nonlinearity, multi-scale nature, and irregularity, just to name a few. As said by Guy Beart,

Turbulence toiler, on the rack, For each step forward, two steps back!

By now, we still don’t fully understand where turbulence comes from (the transition between laminar and turbulent states) and where it goes (toward somewhat ultimate scaling?). Scientists have been working hard on this problem for decades, flaring sparks on the boundless ocean to guide the later generations. And now, it’s our turn to continue this voyage.

Reference

Davidson, P. A., Kaneda, Y., Moffatt, K., & Sreenivasan, K. R. (Eds.). (2011). A Voyage Through Turbulence. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

entry.title: Wall-bounded Turbulence
entry.content:
Turbulent flows are highly dynamic, irregular, and seemingly chaotic, characterized by swirling eddies and coherent structures spanning a wide range of spatiotemporal scales. These complex motions become increasingly rich and fully developed at high Reynolds numbers. Here, we present an instantaneous snapshot of a turbulent channel flow at a friction Reynolds number of 2000, highlighting intricate vortical structures identified using the Q-criterion, a widely used method for vortex visualization. The smaller panels illustrate the evolution of near-wall streaky structures as the Reynolds number increases from 300 to 750 and finally to 2000, revealing a progressive intensification and fragmentation of turbulence.

This figure is generated by me using numerical simulations and is original work.
